Fig. 1 (a) Schematic illustration for the preparation procedure of KH/MgO. (b) XRD patterns, (c) N2 adsorption isotherms, and (d) pore size distributions of the MgO support and the KH/MgO catalyst. (e) SEM image, (f-g) High resolution TEM images, (h) HAADF-STEM image, and (i-k) corresponding EDX elemental maps of KH/MgO. Fig. 2 (a) H2 signal (m/z = 2) monitored by a mass spectrometer during temperature programmed desorption of KH/MgO in an Ar flow. (b) HD signal (m/z = 3) in H2-D2 isotopic exchange experiments performed at room temperature by alternatively feeding H2 or D2 to the samples. Fig. 3 Change of relative concentrations of DPA and its hydrogenation products during hydrogenation catalysis onKH/MgO. Reaction conditions: 80°C, 15 bar H2, 50 mg of KH/MgO, 456 mg of DPA, DPA:KH = 10:1 (molar ratio). 5 ml of mesitylene was used as the solvent. Fig. 4 Catalytic performance of DPA hydrogenation on KH/MgO as a function of (a) reaction temperature (10 bar H2, 10 h, 20 wt% KH/MgO), (b) reaction pressure (80 °C, 10 h, 20 wt% KH/MgO), (c) reaction time (80 °C, 2 bar H2, 20 wt% KH/MgO), and (d) KH loading (80 °C, 15 bar H2, 10 h). Values noted in parentheses indicate the constant reaction conditions used in each set of experiments. In all experiments, molar ratio of DPA to KH is 10:1, and 5 ml mesitylene was used as the solvent. Fig. 5 Comparison of DPA hydrogenation performance on KH/MgO, MgO, commercial KH and KOH/MgO. Graphical abstract Catalytic hydrogenation of alkynes to alkenes is pivotal in both petrochemical and fine chemical industries. Its implementation relies on the use of transition metals, especially those precious Pd-based catalysts. In this work, we utilize a melt infiltration method to prepare magnesium oxide-supported potassium hydride (KH/MgO), which is illustrated as a transition-metal-free catalyst for selective hydrogenation of alkynes. H2-D2 exchange experiment proves that dihydrogen activation and dissociation on KH/MgO is plausible at room temperature and ambient pressure. KH/MgO catalyzes hydrogenation of diphenylacetylene (DPA) already at 40 ℃, implying its high intrinsic activity at very mild conditions. Under an optimized condition of 80°C, 2 bar H2, and 40 h, 75 % conversion of DPA is achieved, affording 82 % selectivity to stilbenes. Mechanistic study suggests that surface hydride on KH/MgO plays an important role toward dihydrogen activation, and involved in the hydrogenation step to form stilbenes. This work shows the promise for using light metal hydrides consisting of earth-abundant elements as alternative hydrogenation catalysts. Keywords Potassium hydride Selective hydrogenation Alkyne Transition-metal-free Mild condition Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Selective hydrogenation of carbon–carbon multiple bonds is an essential step to synthesize bulk chemicals and is of great importance in modern chemical industry [1]. In the petrochemical field, catalytic semi-hydrogenation is the most efficient route to eliminate trace impurities of alkynes and dienes in the olefin feedstocks for downstream polymerization. On the other hand, the hydrogenative transformation of liquid acetylenic (−C≡C−) compounds to high added-value cis- or trans-alkenes provides key building blocks in the production of diverse drugs, vitamins, fragrances, and other fine commodities [2]. To this end, selective hydrogenation of alkynes is a cutting-edge topic in catalysis and has attracted many attentions particularly in recent decades. Currently, many hydrogenation processes rely on the use of precious metal-based catalysts, that being said, palladium is one of the most preferred metals of choice for the hydrogenation catalysis of alkynes because of its high intrinsic activity [3,4]. Unfortunately, the occurrence of side reactions (over-hydrogenation or oligomerization) usually leads to a low selectivity to alkene products on bare palladium. It is believed that the side reactions are caused by the strong adsorption of unsaturated hydrocarbon reactants/intermediates on continuous Pd active sites as well as the high H2 splitting and migration activity. To tackle this challenge, in industry, the famous Lindlar catalyst [5] employs lead acetate or quinoline as a surface modifier to partially block the Pd ensemble sites, and thus achieving high alkene selectivity, however, only at the cost of decreasing the overall catalytic activity. Most recently, bimetallic alloys [6,7], intermetallic compounds [8,9], nano-clusters [10], single-atom catalysts [11–13] and transition metal hydrides [14–16] have been developed to significantly enhance the alkene selectivity toward semi-hydrogenation of various alkyne substrates. These approaches referred as the “site isolation strategy”[3] are able to achieve favorable adsorption configurations of reaction intermediates, which in turn control the energy barriers and manipulate the hydrogenation pathways [17]. In addition, catalytic systems deprived of noble metals, such as nickel-based catalysts were used for selective hydrogenation of alkynes as well [18–21]. These non-noble metal catalysts usually need much higher operating temperatures and hydrogen pressures to display a comparable hydrogenation activity to palladium. Nevertheless, transition metals are essential catalytic components in studies reported so far. Both from the standpoint of sustainability and for understanding the fundamental nature, it is interesting and desirable to explore transition-metal-free hydrogenation catalysts based on earth-abundant elements. Light metal hydrides, such as MgH2 and NaAlH4, have been widely used as hydrogen storage materials due to their reversible hydrogen release and uptake property [22]. One might expect that these hydridic materials can activate dihydrogen and play a role as hydrogen donor, hence functioning as alternative hydrogenation catalysts [23]. It is well known that NaBH4 is a stoichiometric reagent for the reduction of unsaturated functional moiety, including the acetylenic group [24]. However, limited cases have been presented for the selective hydrogenation of alkynes using catalytic amount of light metal hydrides. As an example, alkali metal hydride (LiH, NaH or KH) powders were investigated for catalyzing the selective hydrogenation of 2-pentyne at 190 ℃ under 110 bar H2, only giving a pentene yield of 20 % [25]. Furthermore, carbon supported sodium alanate (NaAlH4) is amenable to hydrogenate liquid alkynes to the corresponding alkenes with decent yields, even though a harsh reaction condition of 150 ℃ and 100 bar H2 is still required [26]. Nanostructuring of metal hydride materials has been demonstrated as a promising strategy to enhance the hydrogen activation/migration kinetics [27,28], therefore improving catalytic activity in hydride-mediated (or hydrogen-involving) reactions. In our previous studies, melt infiltration under H2 pressure was utilized to prepare nano-sized potassium hydride materials. Metallic potassium and a solid support were mixed together and heated above the melting point of potassium. The molten potassium impregnated the support, followed by the in-situ formation of nano-sized KH on the support. These supported potassium hydride materials displayed unique properties in breaking the robust N≡N [29], C−S [30] and C–C [31] bonds under very mild conditions, and thus catalyzing chemical transformations efficiently. This raises an interesting question: whether this type of material, i.e. the nano-sized light metal hydride, could also be used as a heterogeneous catalyst in the absence of transition metals for the selective hydrogenation of alkynes. Herein, we report that magnesium oxide-supported potassium hydride (KH/MgO) can activate dihydrogen at room temperature, and act as a transition-metal-free catalyst for the selective hydrogenation of alkynes at mild conditions. Diphenylacetylene (DPA) was used as a representative substrate to optimize the reaction conditions to achieve high selectivity of alkene products (stilbenes). Surface hydride on KH/MgO plays an important role toward dihydrogen activation and is involved in the hydrogenation step to form stilbenes. 2 Experimental 2.1 General experimental The following chemicals were purchased from the indicated vendors and used as received (solids) or were degassed by three freeze–pump–thaw cycles before use (liquids): metallic potassium (98 %, Alfa), magnesium acetate tetrahydrate (99 %, Aladdin), oxalic acid dihydrate (99 %, Aladdin), potassium hydride (30 wt% dispersion in mineral oil, Adamas, washed carefully with mesitylene and dried in vacuum before use), mesitylene (98 %, Innochem), diphenylacetylene (99 %, Aladdin), cis-stilbene (97 %, Aladdin), trans-stilbene (98 %, Aladdin), bibenzyl (99 %, Aladdin), phenylacetylene (97 %, Aladdin), ethylbenzene (99.5 %, Innochem), 4-ethynyltoluene (98 %, Aladdin), 1-chloro-4-ethynylbenzene (98 %, Aladdin), 1-fluoro-4-ethynylbenzene (98 %, Aladdin), 1-octyne (95 %, Aladdin), 4-octyne (99 %, Aladdin), tridecane (99 %, Aladdin), toluene (99.5 %, Sinopharm). All solid and liquid materials were stored in an argon-filled glove box (Mikrouna, <1 ppm H2O, <1 ppm O2) prior to use. Research-grade gases were supplied from high-pressure cylinders without further purification: deuterium (98 %, MaoToo Runda Gas), hydrogen (99.999 %, Linde Gas) and argon (99.999 %, Linde Gas). Synthesis of KH/MgO and hydrogenation reactions were performed in a high-pressure autoclave from Anhui Kemi Instrument Co., LTD (volume 50 ml, maximum temperature 300 ℃, maximum pressure 200 bar), equipped with magnetic stirring. Identification and quantification of products were performed using a GC-FID (Agilent Technologies 8890A), equipped with a HP-INNOWax Column. Oven temperature program used in a typical GC analysis was i) hold for 1 min at 50 °C, ii) heated to 240 °C with a ramp rate of 10 °C/min, iii) hold for 0.5 min at 240 °C. Ethylbenzene or tridecane was added to the reaction mixture as an internal standard after the reaction. 2.2 Materials synthesis MgO was prepared by a known method [32]. 17.156 g of Mg(CH3COO)2·4H2O and 15.128 g of H2C2O4·2H2O were dissolved in 100 and 350 ml deionized water, respectively. The magnesium acetate solution was added into the oxalic acid solution under magnetic stirring for 3 h. Then this mixture was aged for 10 h at room temperature, followed by filtrating and washing with deionized water, and dried at 110 ℃. The obtained solid powder was calcined in a flow of Ar at 520 ℃ for 4 h. KH/MgO was prepared by a melt impregnation method. In the glovebox, 100 mg of metallic potassium and 400 mg of MgO were physically mixed and placed into an autoclave with a quartz liner. Then the autoclave was sealed, brought out from the glovebox and connected to a high pressure H2 line. The autoclave pressurized to 10 bar of H2, heated to 200 °C with a ramping rate of 5 °C/min, and hold at the desired temperature for 10 h. After cooling down, the solid material in the autoclave was collected under the glovebox atmosphere and carefully mixed by using mortar and pestle. 2.3 Materials characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were conducted on a Bruker AXS D8 Advance XRD instrument using CuKα radiation with a wavelength of 1.5418 Å. An airtight sample holder was used to prevent ingress of air. The diffuse reflectance infrared fourier transform (DRIFT) spectra were acquired by using a Bruker Tensor Ⅱ spectrometer with a resolution of 4 cm−1. Samples were prepared in the glovebox and loaded into an air-tight measurement cell. N2 physisorption measurements were performed at −196 °C using the Micromeritics ASAP 2460 apparatus. Barrett–Joyner–Halenda pore size distribution and mesopore volume were determined from the adsorption branch of isotherms. Scanning transmission electron microscopy and energy dispersive X-ray mapping (STEM-EDX) were acquired using an JEOL JEM-F200 equipped with a high-brightness field emission gun, a high-angle annular dark field (HAADF) detector, and a large collection-angle EDX detector. Scanning electron microscopy-energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (SEM-EDX) was performed using a ZEISS Gemini SEM 360 instrument in the secondary electron mode. Elements analysis (ICP-OES) was performed on a Perkin Elmer avio560 instrument. Temperature programmed desorption (TPD) was performed in an Ar flow of 20 ml min−1 with 50 mg sample using a fixed-bed reactor coupled with a Hiden mass spectroscope. H2 was monitored using the Hiden QIC mass analyser. 2.4 General procedure for the catalytic hydrogenation tests In an Ar-filled glovebox, a certain amount of solid materials (50 mg of KH/MgO, 50 mg of MgO, or 10 mg of commercial KH), 1.28–2.56 mmol of substrates (diphenylacetylene, cis-stilbene, trans-stilbene, phenylacetylene, 4-ethynyltoluene, 1-chloro-4-ethynylbenzene, 1-fluoro-4-ethynylbenzene, 1-octyne, or 4-octyne) and 5–10 ml of solvent (mesitylene or toluene) were added into an autoclave equipped with a quartz liner. The autoclave was sealed, brought out from the glovebox and connected to a high-pressure line of H2 or Ar. The autoclave pressurized to a set pressure of or H2 or Ar and heated to the desired temperature (ramping rate was 5 °C/min). The stirring rate was 600 rpm. After the test, the reaction mixture was open in air, filtered and the supernatant collected and analyzed by GC-FID (ethylbenzene or tridecane was used as the internal standard). For the products analyses of hydrogenation of the diphenylacetylene, retention times obtained using this GC program are: bibenzyl (15.6 min), cis-stilbene (15.9 min), diphenylacetylene (18.5 min), trans-stilbene (19.2 min). A typical gas chromatogram of the reaction mixture after a diphenylacetylene hydrogenation test is shown in Fig. S1. Taken hydrogenation of diphenylacetylene as an example, conversion (X), selectivity (S) and yield (Y) are calculated according to the following equations: X DPA = [ D P A ] 0 - [ D P A ] [ DPA ] 0 × 100 % S i = [ i ] c i s - S T + t r a n s - S T + [ B B ] × 100 % Y i = X DPA × S i × 100 % Where [DPA]0 and [DPA] are the concentrations (mmol/L) of DPA before and after reaction, respectively. [i] is the concentration (mmol/L) of a hydrogenation product after the reaction. 2.5 Hydrogen-deuterium exchange tests Isotopic tests were performed using a gas flow (10 ml min−1) of D2 or H2 at ambient temperature and pressure with 50 mg sample on a fixed-bed reactor. The gaseous products (HD, H2 and D2) were analyzed using an online mass spectrometer (Hiden QGA, Quantitative Gas Analysis System). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization The self-made magnesium oxide nanoplatelets material was employed as the support, which has a high surface area of 208 m2/g and mesoporous structure (average pore diameter of 12 nm). We consider that MgO has basicity and is compatible with alkali metal hydride, and thus was used as the solid support in this study. The KH/MgO catalyst was prepared by melt infiltration and hydrogenation of metallic potassium on the MgO support. A scheme of the synthesis procedure is shown in Fig. 1 a. Following the preparation, X-ray diffraction of KH/MgO contains peaks (Fig. 1b) attributed to magnesium oxide (at 42.8°, 62.1° and 78.4°) and to potassium hydride (mainly at 26.9°, 31.2°, 44.8° and 53.2°). An adsorption peak at 960 cm−1 can be observed in the FT-IR spectrum of KH/MgO (Fig. S2a), which is attributed to the vibration of K-H bond [33]. These results are consistent with the hydrogenation of metallic K by H2. Estimated by the Scherrer equation, the crystallite size of KH on KH/MgO is 39 nm, which suggests that most of the KH nanocrystallites are formed on the surface of MgO. Nitrogen physisorption (Fig. 1c, d and Table S1) demonstrates that, after deposition of KH, the MgO support maintains its mesoporous structure, but surface area and average pore diameter are reduced to 124 m2/g and 10 nm, respectively. This can be explained to the partial block of pore mouths in MgO by KH, which is also supported by the pore volume loss upon the addition of KH (Table S1). Local structure of KH/MgO was characterized using electron microscopes. SEM image shows the stacking structure of MgO (Fig. 1e). As illustrated by the high-resolution transmission electron microscope (HRTEM) image in Fig. 1f, a lattice spacing of 0.21 nm corresponding to the (200) facet of MgO can be observed. Any KH nanocrystallite cannot be observed on the whole MgO domain (Fig. 1g and Fig. S3), likely due to the close mass contrast between K and Mg. However, HAADF-STEM images (Fig. 1h) and EDX mappings (Fig. 1i-k and Fig. S4) indeed reveal the high dispersion of K through the catalyst surface. The loading of K in KH/MgO is 20.1 wt% according to elemental analysis, which is close to the nominal loading of 20 wt% (Table S2). Results of ICP-OES corroborate the high purity of the sample, which contains no trace of any transition metals, such as Pd, Pt, Rh, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Mn, Cr, and Mo (Table S2). 3.2 Dihydrogen activation Hydrogen adsorption and desorption behavior of metal hydride is relevant to hydrogenation catalysis. We herein used temperature programmed desorption (TPD) to evaluate the hydrogen content in KH/MgO and its dynamic release with the rising of temperature. In Fig. 2 a, hydrogen release begins upon heating, with three dominant release peaks at 268, 336, and 485°C, respectively. It should be noted that the amount of hydrogen desorbed between 25 and 100°C is very minor, accounts for mere 3.5 % H in KH. This indicates that the KH/MgO material is stable at low temperatures and very likely only surface hydride vacancies can be created, which is crucial for the subsequent dihydrogen activation and hydrogenation catalysis. In comparison, bare MgO does not produce H2 during heating, while KH itself only desorbs substantial H2 above 300°C (Fig. S5). This distinct H2 desorption behavior of KH/MgO is a clear evidence about the interaction of KH and MgO. Besides, the IR absorption bands of –OH groups in MgO at 3707 cm−1 and 3687 cm−1 vanished upon the deposition of KH (Fig. S2b), which also demonstrates the interaction/reaction of KH with surface hydroxyl groups on MgO. Similar interactions between light metal hydride and metal oxide support via surface hydroxyl groups have been studied [34,35]. Next, we investigated dihydrogen activation on KH/MgO by performing H2-D2 isotopic exchange experiment in a flow reactor. A pure flow of D2 or H2 was fed through the sample alternatively at ambient temperature and pressure, and meanwhile the transient gaseous product, i.e., HD was monitored by a mass spectrometer. As displayed in Fig. 2b, once D2 was introduced to KH/MgO, formation of HD was immediately observed. The signal of HD grows sharply to a maximum in a short period of time (a few minutes), after which it decreases gradually due to the complete exchange of hydrogen in KH/MgO by deuterium. This itinerary production of HD by alternative feeding of D2 and H2 evidences the feasibility of dihydrogen activation on KH/MgO even under ambient conditions. In contrast, no detectable hydrogen isotopic exchange activity is observed on either bulk KH or the bare MgO support. Dihydrogen activation on metal hydride is expected to initially occur via surface adsorption and dissociation. Therefore, it can be understood that the high dispersion of KH, and thus, giving accessibility of active sites is essential for efficient hydrogen activation. 3.3 Catalytic hydrogenation testing We examined the hydrogenation catalysis of KH/MgO by employing diphenylacetylene (DPA) as a showcase substrate (Scheme 1 ). Fig. 3 shows the change of relative concentrations of DPA and hydrogenation products with reaction time on KH/MgO, under the conditions of 80°C and 15 bar H2 using a 10:1 M ratio of DPA to KH. Interestingly, trans-stilbene (trans-ST) is dominant as the main product in 10 h. Longer reaction time leads to the consumption of both trans-ST and cis-ST by their over-hydrogenation to bibenzyl (BB). After 30 h, a full conversion of DPA to BB is observed. It is clear that KH/MgO can hydrogenate both alkyne and alkene groups, and the hydrogenation behavior is catalytic, rather than caused by any stoichiometric reaction. As reaction conditions determine the catalytic activity and products distribution, then we evaluate how the reaction temperature, H2 pressure, reaction time, and the weight loading of KH on MgO influence the DPA conversion and selectivity to stilbenes. Under 10 bar H2, hydrogenation of DPA already proceeds at 40 °C (Fig. 4 a). At this temperature, selectivity to stilbenes is 100 % yet the conversion of DPA is low. With the increase of reaction temperature from 40 to 80 °C, conversion of DPA rises sharply from 3 % to 63 %, and still selectivity to stilbenes remains above 85 %. Higher temperatures provide full conversion of DPA, however, this leads to the over-hydrogenation of stilbenes to BB (Fig. 4a). Interestingly, 33 % conversion of DPA and 95 % selectivity to stilbenes are achieved at 2 bar H2 and 80 °C (Fig. 4b), which indicates the high intrinsic semi-hydrogenation activity of KH/MgO under mild reaction conditions. Conversion of DPA increases two times with the H2 pressure such that selectivity to stilbenes slightly decreases from 95 % to 85 %. As the hydrogenation selectivity is controlled by kinetics, longer reaction time can improve the reaction conversion, however decreasing the selectivity to stilbenes as a compromise. Noteworthy, 83 % selectivity to stilbenes (mostly the trans-stilbene) is achieved at a high conversion of DPA, i.e., 75 % (Fig. 4c). In addition, the change of stilbenes selectivity as a function of DPA conversion under the same reaction conditions can be seen in Fig. S6. When the weight loading of KH on MgO is varied from 10 % to 30 wt%, interestingly, conversion of DPA shows a volcano-type dependence (Fig. 4d). The increased catalytic activity with the KH loading below 25 wt% might be related to the rise and accessibility of active sites. On the other hand, the decreasing activity on the high KH loading catalyst could be related to the crystallite size of KH, which is larger in 30 wt% KH/C (46 nm) relative to 25 wt% KH/C (39 nm). It is well known that the active surface area decreases with the rising of catalyst’s crystallite size. Experiments performed with the recovered KH/MgO in the conditions of 80 °C, 1.5 MPa, 10 h, and a 10:1 M ratio of DPA to KH show that the conversion of diphenylacetylene is sustained at 82 %-84 % and selectivities to stilbenes and bibenzyl are very similar among three catalytic cycles (Fig. S7). XRD shows the same phase (viz. KH and MgO) in the diffractogram for the fresh and recovered KH/MgO (Fig. S8), which supports the good catalytic stability of KH/MgO. Similar DPA hydrogenation activities were achieved when varying the KH/MgO catalyst loading from 30 mg to 70 mg (ratio of DPA to KH used was kept as 10:1), which excludes the presence of mass transfer limitations (Fig. S9). In addition, a series of control experiments were performed to demonstrate the superiority of the nano-sized KH/MgO catalyst in hydrogenation reaction (Fig. 5 ). Bare MgO shows negligible hydrogenation activity of DPA even at 150°C and 15 bar H2. Conversion of DPA on MgO is explained to its adsorption on the porous support with a high surface area. Notably, under the same reaction conditions (80°C, 15 bar H2, 10:1 M ratio of DPA to KH), KH/MgO exhibits 52 times higher stilbenes yield than that with commercial KH. Magnesium oxide supported potassium hydroxide (KOH/MgO) is inactive for hydrogenative transformation of DPA, evidencing the essential role of hydride species in promoting hydrogenation catalysis. A comparison of DPA hydrogenation activity on different heterogeneous catalysts is given in Table S3. Noble metals are commonly used catalysts for DPA hydrogenation. The reaction can be performed on Pd at ambient conditions, however, activities are strongly depended on the use of supports (96 % conversion of DPA on Pd/SiO2 versus 17 % on Pd/MCM-22)[36]. Other noble metals such as Pt, Rh, and Ru show less activities than Pd, and the over-hydrogenation to bibenzyl on these nanocatalysts cannot be circumvented [37]. Recently, unsaturated Ni(II) sites confined in Y-zeolite (Ni@Y) exhibited complete conversion of DPA and exclusive selectivity to stilbenes at 175 °C and 10 bar H2, demonstrating the promising of site segregation strategy on improving the performance of selective hydrogenation [38]. In comparison with the previously reported novel metal hydride catalyst NaAlH4/C [26], KH/MgO can be operated at much lower temperatures and pressures, as well as achieving higher stilbene selectivity under optimized reaction conditions. Furthermore, a number of other substrates including both aromatic and aliphatic alkynes were tested to demonstrate the scope of selective hydrogenation catalysis using KH/MgO (Table 1 ). Subjecting to the standard reaction conditions (80 °C and 15 bar H2), almost complete conversion of phenylacetylene (entry 1) is achieved, with 65 % selectivity to styrene. The substrate of 4-ethynyltoluene (entry 2) affords 80 % selectivity to 4-methylstyrene at a conversion of 85 %. In addition, KH/MgO can also enable the selective hydrogenation of phenylacetylene derivatives substituted with heteroatom-containing functional groups. At 120 °C and 20 bar H2, hydrogenation of 1-chloro-4-ethynylbenzene (entry 3) exhibits 91 % conversion and 70 % selectivity to 4-chlorostyrene. 1-fluoro-4-ethynylbenzene (entry 4) subjected to the same conditions produces high yield of 4-fluorostyrene (92 % selectivity) at a conversion of 68 %. In terms of the aliphatic substrates, 98 % conversion of 1-octyne (entry 5) on KH/MgO is observed, which accounts for 77 % selectivity to 1-octene. Reaction of 4-octyne (entry 6) on KH/MgO results in 65 % conversion and 82 % selectivity to 4-octene. 3.4 Proposed reaction mechanism In order to gain insight into the hydrogenation mechanism using KH/MgO, particularly, whether hydride in KH can be involved in the hydrogenation step, the reaction of DPA on KH/MgO was tested in the absence of H2. At 80 °C and 3 bar Ar, DPA conversion is 21 % and the reaction only affords cis-ST and trans-ST in low yield of 1 % and 3 %, respectively. The mass balance problem is due to the adsorption of DPA on MgO, as the result tested on a bare MgO. Production of stilbenes without H2 indicates that semi-hydrogenation of DPA can proceed via extraction of hydrogen from the KH. Because the molar ratio of KH to DPA used is 1:10, the 4 % stilbenes yield corresponds to 0.8 % H (4 %*2/10 = 0.8 %) in KH of KH/MgO. Therefore, the hydrogenation catalysis exclusively occurs on the surface of the catalyst. Surface hydride as a hydrogen source participates into the hydrogenation reaction, followed by the formation of hydride vacancies, and then these hydride vacancies can be replenished by gaseous hydrogen (as the dihydrogen activation claimed in section 3.2). Trans-stilbene is the thermodynamically more stable isomer than its cis- counterpart [36]. Our studies observed both the formation of cis- and trans-stilbenes on KH/MgO under all the reaction conditions applied. To this end, an interesting question is whether one isomer product comes from the isomerization of the other one. Previous literature reported that the cis–trans isomerization of alkene always requires the half breaking of a C=C bond into the corresponding single bond, so that a free rotation of the molecular frame along with the C−C axis is allowed [37]. Surprisingly, there is no any hydrogenation activity can be observed using either cis-stilbene or trans-stilbene as a substrate (Table S4), possibly due to the steric hinderance of bulky diphenyl groups (preventing adsorption of stilbenes on KH/MgO). The fact of low affinity of cis-ST and trans-ST on KH/MgO also supports that, once stilbenes are formed, which prefer to desorb from the catalyst surface rather than implementing isomerization. We tentatively hypothesize that hydrogenation occurs stepwise on KH/MgO, with first the formation of cis-ST and trans-ST from DPA via likely two separate pathways, followed by over-hydrogenation to BB (Scheme 2 ). Potassium alkyl carbanion species could be important hydrogenation intermediates during the catalysis process mediated by alkali metal hydride [25,31]. However, in order to better understand the nature of reactive intermediates and elementary steps, further investigation is required. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, we presented the synthesis of nanostructured KH on MgO with high surface area. The present work demonstrates that dihydrogen activation is feasible on KH/MgO at room temperature and ambient pressure, which enables hydrogenation of alkynes at very mild conditions. Taken the diphenylacetylene substrate as a showcase, selectivity to stilbene products can be improved by optimizing the reaction conditions (temperature, pressure, time etc.), as the consecutive hydrogenation catalysis is kinetically controlled. It is envisaged that, other alkali or alkali earth metals, which are the analogues of KH, when supported on a proper solid support, can be also very active for selective hydrogenation of alkynes. Further work shall focus on the fabrication of diverse supported alkali or alkali earth metal hydride nanomaterials and on the elucidation of the influence of different metal cations as well as the underlying hydrogenation mechanism. coredata.dc:description: Catalytic hydrogenation of alkynes to alkenes is pivotal in both petrochemical and fine chemical industries. Its implementation relies on the use of transition metals, especially those precious Pd-based catalysts. In this work, we utilize a melt infiltration method to prepare magnesium oxide-supported potassium hydride (KH/MgO), which is illustrated as a transition-metal-free catalyst for selective hydrogenation of alkynes. H2-D2 exchange experiment proves that dihydrogen activation and dissociation on KH/MgO is plausible at room temperature and ambient pressure. KH/MgO catalyzes hydrogenation of diphenylacetylene (DPA) already at 40 ℃, implying its high intrinsic activity at very mild conditions. Under an optimized condition of 80°C, 2 bar H2, and 40 h, 75 % conversion of DPA is achieved, affording 82 % selectivity to stilbenes. Mechanistic study suggests that surface hydride on KH/MgO plays an important role toward dihydrogen activation, and involved in the hydrogenation step to form stilbenes. This work shows the promise for using light metal hydrides consisting of earth-abundant elements as alternative hydrogenation catalysts.
